prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my sister’s boyfriend he’s not “family”?
My sister has been dating this guy for less than three months.  My personal feelings are that he’s an idiot.  I mean he’s young (either late teens or early twenties, idk) so it’s understandable.  I was an idiot back then too.  My problem with him is that he’s made some dangerous choices with my sister involved.  He wrecked his truck with her in it driving drunk.  He also took my sister around this ex felon that everyone in town knows is scary dude just so he could buy some “pot” if it was really pot.  The guy sells a lot more than pot.  He’s definitely not someone I want knowing or getting close with my sister.  

Despite that, it’s her choice who she dates so I’ve kept my opinions to myself until now.  I think he mistook politeness for friendship or something.  He’s shown up at my apartment to hang out.  When I visit my mom’s and he’s there he will basically attache himself to my hip.  Most annoying of all he started calling me brother and fam.  I know those aren’t always specifically referring to actual family, but it’s just what it’s felt like.  

It really got under my skin quickly.  The last time he did it I told him, “You’re not my family.  You’re the guy my sister is dating for now.”   He just said “alright” and I walked away. 

He’s just trying to be friendly and get close with his girlfriend’s family, I understand that.  It felt like it was time for a reality check on our relationship though.  I probably pissed my sister off in the process, I haven’t heard from her since it happened.  



"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

Okay, let's try to work through this. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is about the author telling their sister's boyfriend that he's not family. 

First, I need to understand the context. The sister has been dating this guy for less than three months. The author has some issues with him because he made dangerous choices, like driving drunk with the sister in the car and hanging out with a known ex-felon to buy drugs. The author is worried about the sister's safety but has kept to themselves until now.

The brother-in-law (the author) feels that the boyfriend was overstepping by coming to his apartment, attaching himself when he visits their mom, and using familial terms like "brother" and "fam." The breaking point was when the author told him he isn't family, which probably upset the sister.

So, the key points here are the author's concerns about the boyfriend's safety and the boyfriend's behavior of trying to be part of the family. The author is trying to set boundaries, which is understandable, but might have come off as harsh. 

But is the author in the wrong? Well, they have a right to be concerned about their sister's well-being. However, telling someone they're not family might be seen as dismissive or rude. The author didn't attack the boyfriend's character directly but set a boundary. It's possible that the approach was a bit abrupt, but given the circumstances, it's a justified reaction to prevent the boyfriend from feeling too included in the family when the author isn't comfortable.

Also, considering the sister's choice in dating is her own right, but the author is protecting their family. The boyfriend's actions were risky, so the author's intervention could be seen as protective. However, the method of communication might have been a problem. The author didn't confront the sister first or talk to the boyfriend privately in a different way. 

But the main question is whether the author is in the wrong. Since the author had valid concerns and tried to address the overfamiliar behavior, even if it was direct, they might not be wrong. On the other hand, the way they communicated it could have been handled more delicately to avoid hurting the sister's feelings. However, the answer hinges on whether the action was unjustified. The author's actions were in response to the boyfriend's overstepping, so B (not in the wrong) seems appropriate.
